title-group.article-title: A 950 yr temperature reconstruction from Duckhole Lake, southern Tasmania, Australia

article-meta.aff: 1Institute of Geography and the Oeschger Center for Climate Change Research, University of Bern, Switzerland
2Institute for Marine & Antarctic Studies, University of Tasmania, Australia
3British Antarctic Survey, Natural Environment Research Council, UK

author-notes.corresp: Krystyna M Saunders, Institute of Geography and the Oeschger Center for Climate Change Research, University of Bern, Bern 3012, Switzerland. Email: krystyna.saunders@giub.unibe.ch

abstract.p: A lack of quantitative high resolution paleoclimate data from the Southern Hemisphere limits the ability to examine current trends within the context of long-term natural climate variability. This study presents a temperature reconstruction for southern Tasmania based on analyses of a sediment core from Duckhole Lake (43.365°S, 146.875°E). The relationship between non-destructive whole core scanning reflectance spectroscopy measurements in the visible spectrum (380–730 nm) and the instrumental temperature record (ad 1911–2000) was used to develop a calibration-in-time reflectance spectroscopy-based temperature model. Results showed that a trough in reflectance from 650 to 700 nm, which represents chlorophyll and its derivatives, was significantly correlated to annual mean temperature. A calibration model was developed (R = 0.56, pauto < 0.05, root mean squared error of prediction (RMSEP) = 0.21°C, five-year filtered data, calibration period 1911–2000) and applied down-core to reconstruct annual mean temperatures in southern Tasmania over the last c. 950 years. This indicated that temperatures were initially cool c. ad 1050, but steadily increased until the late ad 1100s. After a brief cool period in the ad 1200s, temperatures again increased. Temperatures steadily decreased during the ad 1600s and remained relatively stable until the start of the 20th century when they rapidly decreased, before increasing from ad 1960s onwards. Comparisons with high resolution temperature records from western Tasmania, New Zealand and South America revealed some similarities, but also highlighted differences in temperature variability across the mid-latitudes of the Southern Hemisphere. These are likely due to a combination of factors including the spatial variability in climate between and within regions, and differences between records that document seasonal (i.e. warm season/late summer) versus annual temperature variability. This highlights the need for further records from the mid-latitudes of the Southern Hemisphere in order to constrain past natural spatial and seasonal/annual temperature variability in the region, and to accurately identify and attribute changes to natural variability and/or anthropogenic activities.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: The importance of reconstructing natural climate variability over the last 1000–2000 years and differentiating between natural and human-induced climate change is increasingly recognized (Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC), 2007). However, there is still a lack of data from the Southern Hemisphere, which limits understanding global climate variability in the pre-instrumental period, the ability to place recent observed temperature trends into context and identify the causes of variability (IPCC, 2007; Neukom and Gergis, 2012). This has led to recent research efforts to develop more paleoclimate records and regional syntheses from the Southern Hemisphere (e.g. the Past Global Changes (PAGES) 2k network: Aus2k, LOTRED-SA, Africa2k, Antarctica2k; see http://www.pages-igbp.org/science/foci/focus-2/themes/2k-network and Neukom and Gergis 2012). Tasmania (41–43°S) is an important location for investigating past climate variability in the Southern Hemisphere mid-latitudes (Figure 1). Its maritime, cool temperate climate is influenced by a number of atmospheric and oceanic patterns including the El Niño Southern Oscillation, Southern Annular Mode (SAM), Indian Ocean Dipole and blocking highs in the Tasman Sea (Grose et al., 2010). This means paleoclimate records may provide insights into larger-scale regional and hemispheric climate changes. For example, Cook et al. (1991, 2000, 2006) developed a quantitative high resolution warm season (November–April) temperature reconstruction spanning the last 3592 years based on tree rings in western Tasmania and linked the changes to sea level pressure variability, ocean dynamics and regional climate teleconnections. Allen et al. (2001) linked tree ring widths from an Athrotaxis cupressoides network across Tasmania to changes in the Southern Oscillation Index, SAM and Inter-decadal Pacific Oscillation. Saunders et al. (2012) developed an annual precipitation reconstruction for northwest Tasmania based on a lake sediment record and linked the changes to fluctuations in the Southern Hemisphere westerly winds.

caption.p: (a) Location of Tasmania; (b) location of Duckhole Lake and mean annual temperature distribution across Tasmania (based on Forest Education Foundation, 2010); (c) Duckhole Lake

sec.p: Lake sediments may be used to develop quantitative annual or seasonal climate reconstructions (Pienitz et al., 2009). One approach is to calibrate proxy data to meteorological data over the instrumental period and then extend this relationship to reconstruct meteorological parameters back in time (i.e. calibration-in-time (CIT)). While this approach is widely used in d endroclimatology (e.g. Cook et al., 1994; Esper et al., 2005), it is less widely applied to lake sediments, although the number of studies is increasing (e.g. Elbert et al., 2012; Kaufman et al., 2011; McKay et al., 2008; Saunders et al., 2012; Trachsel et al., 2010a, 2010b; von Gunten et al., 2009, 2012). Application of CIT to lake sediments relies on a number of assumptions and requirements: (i) the lake needs a high enough sedimentation rate and accurate chronology to provide sufficient data tie points for the calibration period; (ii) the established statistical proxy-climate relationship may be explained by a process; and (iii) the statistical relationship between the proxy and climate variable is stable over time. This last assumption applies to all proxy-based climate reconstructions (Birks et al., 2012). One particular challenge for any CIT approach is potential long-term trends in the time series that are caused by non-climatic processes (e.g. age trends in tree ring widths or long-term lake development). In these cases proxy time series should be detrended to remove potential non-climatic trends (Trachsel et al., 2010b; von Storch et al., 2004).

The use of non-destructive sediment core scanning methods (e.g. x-ray fluorescence, reflectance spectroscopy) means sediment cores may be analyzed at a high resolution (2 mm or finer). The development of detailed 210Pb-based sediment chronologies and analyses of lakes with relatively high accumulation rates means CIT may be used in regions where varved/annually laminated lake sediments are not available (von Gunten et al., 2012). For example, a CIT approach based on scanning reflectance spectroscopy in the visible spectrum (VIS-RS, 380–730 nm) has been used to develop temperature (e.g. Trachsel et al., 2010a; von Gunten et al., 2009) and precipitation (e.g. Saunders et al., 2012) reconstructions.
The aims of this study were to:

list-item.p: develop and apply a CIT model based on VIS-RS data to reconstruct temperature in southern Tasmania over the last c. 950 years; and

compare the temperature reconstruction to previously published temperature records from Tasmania and other mid-latitude regions of the Southern Hemisphere, and investigate similarities and differences between regions.

sec.title: Study area
sec.p: The island state of Tasmania lies off the southeast coast of the Australian continent (Figure 1). It has a temperate maritime climate and temperatures are modulated by the surrounding ocean (Grose et al., 2010). The main characteristic of Tasmania’s climate is the interaction between the prevailing westerly winds and mountain ranges near the west coast and central plateau. These primarily influence rainfall across the island (i.e. the west is much wetter than the east), but do influence temperature changes. Seasonal temperature ranges are relatively small (i.e. mean maximum temperatures in summer range from 18–23°C and 9–14 °C in winter; Grose et al., 2010).

Tasmania experienced stable mean temperatures for the first half of the 20th century. Since the ad 1940s, mean temperatures have risen by more than 0.5°C, which is less than the Australian and global averages (Grose et al., 2010). The increase was greatest in summer and larger for minimum temperature than maximum temperature. Model projections indicate that increases in annual mean, minimum and maximum temperatures are likely to be relatively uniform across Tasmania in the 21st century. However, seasonal changes are projected to have more spatial variability, which has been attributed to seasonal changes in the winds. For example, the gradient of temperature change in summer is projected to be greatest near the west coast, which may be related to the projected reduction in the prevailing westerly winds during summer and consequently a reduction in cool air blown off the ocean (Grose et al., 2010).

Duckhole Lake (43.36455°S, 146.87492°E, 150m above sea level) is a small (0.25 km2), relatively shallow (3.3 m deep), freshwater, acidic sinkhole lake in southern Tasmania (Figure 1, Table 1). The vegetation immediately surrounding the lake is Nothofagus rainforest and the dominant canopy species are Nothofagus cunninghamii, Eucalyptus obliqua and Atherosperma moschatum. The area was first explored by Europeans in the early ad 1800s and forestry soon developed as the main industry in the area. Forestry remains important today, together with agriculture, aquaculture and tourism (Huon Council, 2011).

caption.p: Water chemistry data for Duckhole Lake (measured 22 January 2010).

sec.title: Water chemistry and sediment core collection
sec.p: Water samples were collected for water chemistry (nutrients and major ions) analyses, which were performed at Analytical Services Tasmania (following nutrients APHA 4500, using flow injection analysis, and molybdate reactive silica APHA 4500, molybdate blue stannous chloride methods). A Hydrolab Multisonde 5 was used to measure temperature, conductivity, dissolved oxygen, turbidity and pH of the lake water on site.

A 91.6 cm long sediment core was collected from Duckhole Lake (17 April 2009) using a UWITEC gravity corer with a percussion hammer. The sediment core was wrapped in black plastic immediately after collection to ensure the sediment was not exposed to light. It was sealed and transported to the University of Bern, Switzerland, where it was split longitudinally. One half (DH_1A) was used to develop a chronology for the core, while the other (DH_1B) was scanned using VIS-RS before subsampling for geochemical analyses. All material was stored at 4°C in the dark.

sec.title: Sediment chronology
sec.p: The sediment chronology was established using 210Pb (Appleby and Oldfield, 1978) and 14C dating methods (Ramsey, 2008). The top 20 cm of DH_1A was sectioned at 0.5 cm intervals and freeze-dried. Sixteen samples for 210Pb dating were initially analyzed by gamma spectroscopy, but the activities were too low, so alpha spectroscopy was used instead to measure decay of 210Pb and 226Ra (Eakins and Morrison, 1978). Nine samples were measured on an HPGe gamma detector for 137Cs. These analyses were undertaken at the Flett Research Institute Ltd, Winnipeg, Canada.

The Constant Rate of Supply (CRS) model (Appleby and Oldfield, 1978) constrained to the peak in 137Cs activity, which corresponds to ad 1964 in the Southern Hemisphere (The Environmental Measurements Laboratory, 2008), was used to develop the chronology for the calibration period. To verify the chronology, the modeled age of the sediment at the depth when 137Cs first appeared was checked as this should correspond to ad 1954–1955 (Hancock et al., 2011).

For the remainder of the core, five terrestrial plant macrofossil samples were 14C dated using Accelerator Mass Spectrometry at the Poznań Radiocarbon Laboratory, Poznań, Poland, and calibrated with the Southern Hemisphere Calibration curve (SHCal04, McCormac et al., 2004).

The final age–depth model based on 210Pb and calibrated 14C dates was developed using a mixed-effect regression model by Heegaard et al. (2005) with default parameters. All dates are in calendar years (ad) to allow comparisons with other records.

sec.title: Reflectance spectroscopy (VIS-RS)
sec.p: DH_1B was scanned at 2 mm intervals using a Gretag-Spectrolino (GretagMcBeth, Switzerland). Reflectance spectra were measured at 10 nm intervals in the visible light range (380–730 nm).

Lithogenic content (an estimate of mica, illite and chlorite) was calculated using the ratio of reflectance between 570 and 630 nm (R570/630; Rein and Sirocko, 2002, 2003). The degree of diagenesis (a relative measure of the amount of chlorophyll-related degradation products) was calculated using the ratio of reflectance between 660 and 670 nm (R660/670; Rein and Sirocko, 2002, 2003).

Previous studies have demonstrated that the trough area between 650 and 700 nm corresponds to the concentration of chlorophyll a and its derivatives (Das, 2007; Michelutti et al., 2010; Wolfe et al., 2006). The size of the trough was determined by calculating the area of the trough near 675 nm (R650;700; Wolfe et al., 2006) and the relative absorption band depth from 660 to 670 nm (RABD660;670; Rein and Sirocko, 2002, 2003):

Where y1 = reflectance at 650 nm, y2 = reflectance at 700 nm, x = 50 (as this is the difference between y1 and y2), and SUM(R650-R700) is the sum of the difference between each 10 nm interval from 650 to 700 nm. See Wolfe et al. (2006) for further details.

Where R590 = reflectance at 590 nm, R730 = reflectance at 730 nm, 13 = the number of 10 nm intervals between 590 and 730 nm, Rmin(660;670) = minimum reflectance between 660 and 670 nm, and Rmean = mean reflectance from 420 to 730 nm. See Rein and Sirocko (2002, 2003) for further details.

sec.title: Sediment geochemistry
sec.p: Once scanned, DH_1B was cut at 2 mm intervals. Wet samples were weighed and freeze-dried (−80°C) for three days. After drying, the samples were re-weighed and the water content was determined (Menounos, 1997). Total Organic Carbon (TOC) and total nitrogen (TN) were determined using 20–50 mg of dried sediment using a Macro Vario elemental analyzer. Biogenic silica (BSi) analysis was undertaken on ~ 100 mg (range 97.0–121.8 mg) dried sample using a wet chemical extraction method based on alkaline leaching and inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectrometry following Ohlendorf and Sturm (2008). TOC, TN and BSi analyses were undertaken at 2 mm intervals for the upper 20 cm and at 1 cm intervals for the remainder of the sediment core.

sec.title: Meteorological data
sec.p: Meteorological data (mean monthly maximum temperature, mean monthly minimum temperature, mean monthly mean temperature and total monthly precipitation) was obtained from the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation (CSIRO) Australian Water Availability Project (AWAP), which produced 0.05° latitude × 0.05° longitude resolution gridded (precipitation and temperature) data for Australia (Jones et al., 2009).

sec.title: Statistical analyses – development and application of the calibration model
sec.p: To investigate potential relationships between proxy data and meteorological time series, calibration analyses were restricted to the instrumental period (ad 1911–2000). The irregular proxy data were initially regularized by linear interpolation to calendar years (Kamenik et al., 2009; von Gunten et al., 2012). Non-detrended Pearson correlations were developed between proxies and meteorological data. Each proxy was correlated with 1–12 month means of temperature (monthly mean, maximum and minimum temperature) and precipitation (total monthly precipitation; de Jong and Kamenik, 2011). To account for potential lagged responses in the proxy data, the monthly to annual meteorological data were also shifted 1–11 months into the past (de Jong and Kamenik, 2011). The probability (p) values were corrected for serial autocorrelation (pauto; Bayley and Hammersley, 1946) and multiple testing (Benjamini and Hochberg, 1995; de Jong and Kamenik, 2011).

Once significant correlations between proxy and meteorological data were determined, all data were smoothed using a five-year triangular filter. The width of the filter was selected to take into account sampling measurement errors and dating uncertainties, while still retaining a high number of degrees of freedom (Kamenik et al., 2009).

Other factors such as lake development and human impacts may contribute to a long-term trend in the proxy data that is not related to climate (von Storch et al., 2004). To ensure that the identified correlations were related to climate variables, proxy and meteorological data were detrended, and only those correlations maintaining significance when detrended were used for developing calibration models (Kamenik et al., 2009). This ensures the derived correlations are not just due to trends in the data. Detrending was based on locally weighted regression (Loess (span = 0.7); Cleveland and Devlin, 1988). LOESS detrending was chosen as it is not affected by the length of the record (Kamenik et al., 2009).

The calibration model was developed using linear inverse prediction based on ordinary least-squares (OLS) regression (i.e. January–December mean temperature as the predictor and R650;700 as the response variable; see Results). Linear inverse prediction was used as it retains the variance better than linear inverse regression (Trachsel et al., 2010b). This approach is the most common method when applying CIT to lake sediments (Elbert et al., 2012; Trachsel et al., 2010b; von Gunten et al., 2009, 2012).

Model performance was assessed by calculating the root mean squared error of prediction (RMSEP) from 10-fold (Legendre and Legendre, 1998) and leave-one-out (jackknifing) cross validation (Birks et al., 2012). These may underestimate RMSEP in autocorrelated time series (Telford and Birks, 2009). However, using the entire instrumental period (rather than a ‘split period’ approach, which is commonly applied in tree ring research; Cook et al., 1994) means a broader range of variability is incorporated in the calibration model (von Gunten et al., 2012). The reconstruction was smoothed by 21 years (using a triangular filter) to take into account dating uncertainty in the sediment core.

All statistical analyses were conducted in R (R Core Development Team, 2009) using the add-on packages Vegan (Oksanen et al., 2007), Boot (Canty and Ripley, 2010), Car (Fox and Weisberg, 2010) and nlme (Pinheiro and Bates, 2009). Stratigraphic plots were developed in C2 version 1.5 (Juggins, 2007).

sec.title: Sediment description
sec.p: The lithology of the Duckhole Lake sediment core primarily consisted of organic gyttja and had a structure of ultra fine organics. The color alternated throughout the length of the sediment core between bands of dark and light brown. A distinct band of dark brown highly organic material that was different from the rest of the sediment core occurred from 49–61.6 cm. However, the sediment above and below this band had the same lithology and texture. Terrestrial plant macrofossils occurred at different depth intervals, in particular near the surface, from 26–30 cm, 37.6 cm, 47 cm, 55–58 cm and 79.6 and 89.5 cm.

sec.title: Sediment chronology
sec.p: The 210Pb activities (both supported and unsupported) were low (i.e. unsupported 210Pb at the surface was 31.15 Bq/kg). Total 210Pb indicated an exponential decay in the surface sediments, which suggests no significant mixing (e.g. due to wave action or bioturbation) and an undisturbed sediment–water interface. 210Pb reached measurable background after 10 cm (Figure 2a). 137Cs appeared at 7.5 cm and peaked at 4.5 cm (Figure 2a), providing an additional tie point. The chronology for the calibration period was determined using the CRS model constrained to the 137Cs peak at 4.5 cm (Figure 2b). This yielded an age of 1952 ± 2.4 years at 7.5 cm, which corresponds to the first appearance of 137Cs in lake sediments, providing additional support for the derived age–depth model.

caption.p: Age–depth model for the Duckhole Lake sediment core. (a) Total 210Pb, 226Ra and 137Cs activities; (b) 210Pb-based CRS age–depth model constrained to the 137Cs peak at 4.5 cm for the calibration period (ad 1911–2009); and (c) combined 210Pb and 14C age–depth model

sec.p: The base of the core was 990 ± 40 14C yr BP (Table 2) and radiocarbon dates were in stratigraphic order. The final age–depth model indicated relatively stable sedimentation rates throughout the c. 950 year history of the sediment core with periods of slightly lower modeled sedimentation from 47 to 55.5 cm and from 79.5 cm to the base of the core (Figure 2c). The sedimentation rate determined by the 14C and 210Pb dates suggested no abrupt change with the arrival of Europeans in the ad 1800s and relatively constant sedimentation rates throughout the calibration period. Due to the relatively large uncertainty of the age–depth model (Figure 2c), all time periods referred to are cited as approximate age ranges (denoted by c.).

caption.p: Summary of 14C dates and calibrated values. All dates were calibrated using the Southern Hemisphere calibration curve and ‘clam’ (Blaauw, 2010).

sec.title: Reflectance spectroscopy
sec.p: VIS-RS data are summarized in Figure 3. R570/630 and R660/670 fluctuated throughout the core with a slight overall decreasing trend towards the surface. R570/630 was significantly positively correlated to R660/670 (R = 0.5, p < 0.05). R650;700 and RABD660;670 were highly significantly correlated (R = 0.95, p < 0.05) and weakly correlated to R660/670 (both R = 0.36). R650;700, RABD660;670 and R660/670 were significantly correlated with water content (R = 0.52, 0.60 and 0.53, respectively, p < 0.05). Once corrected for water content, the correlation between R650;700 and R660/670 increased (R = 0.41, p < 0.05), while there was no longer a correlation between RABD660;670 and R660/670.

caption.p: Stratigraphic plots for the Duckhole Lake sediment core, including a photograph of the sediment core. Lithogenic content (R570-630), pigment diagenesis (R660/670), total chlorin (1 and 2) and water content were measured on the entire core at 2 mm intervals. Total chlorin (1) = trough area (R650/700; note scale is reversed, based on Wolfe et al., 2006). Total chlorin (2) = RABD660;670 (based on Rein and Sirocko, 2002, 2003). TOC, TN and BSi were measured at 2 mm resolution for the upper 20 cm and 1cm resolution from 20 cm to the base of the sediment core. TOC:TN refers to the TOC to TN ratio

sec.title: Sediment geochemistry
sec.p: TOC was relatively high throughout the sediment core, peaking at 32%, while TN was relatively low, peaking at 1.08% (both at 52.8 cm; Figure 3). The TOC:TN ratio ranged from 22.7 (in the surface sample) to 34.6 (at 79.8 cm), and averaged 29.4. BSi fluctuated throughout the sediment core, peaking at 3.97% at 55.8 cm and water content was high throughout the sediment core (range 60–80%). An increase in TOC, TN, BSi and water content occurred from 49 to 61.6 cm (Figure 3). All these parameters also increased towards the top of the core (7.0 cm to the surface).

R650;700 was highly significantly correlated to TOC (R = 0.85, p < 0.05), while RABD660;670 was slightly less so (R = 0.83, p < 0.05). This correlation was maintained, even when R650;700 and RABD660;670 were corrected for water content (R = 0.86 and 0.79, respectively, p < 0.05).

sec.title: Calibration with meteorological data
sec.p: All VIS-RS-derived proxies (R650;700, RABD660;670, R660/670 and R570/630) were calibrated to monthly and annual temperature (mean, maximum and minimum) and precipitation (total) for the period ad 1911–2000. R650;700 was most highly and significantly correlated to mean annual (January–December) temperature (R = 0.84, pauto < 0.05, pauto after detrending < 0.05).

The correlation between R650;700 and annual temperature was highly significant after applying a five-year triangular filter (non-detrended: R = 0.85, pauto < 0.001; Figure 4a) and remained significant when detrended (R = 0.29, pauto < 0.05; Figure 4b). While the correlation was, as expected, weaker when the data were detrended, the p value was still significant and remained significant when corrected for autocorrelation. RABD660;670 also had a significant correlation with annual temperature, but the correlation was not as high (R = 0.71, pauto < 0.05) and was not significant when the data were detrended and tested for autocorrelation (i.e. pauto after detrending > 0.05). R660/670 and R570/630 were significantly correlated with winter–spring mean temperature, but the correlations did not remain significant when the data were detrended. None of the proxies were significantly correlated to precipitation (monthly, seasonal or annual). This means RABD660;670, R660/670 and R570/630 were not suitable for developing CIT models, but R650;700 was suitable for developing an annual mean temperature CIT model.

caption.p: Comparison of R650;700 and annual mean temperature: (a) non-detrended R650;700 and mean annual temperature; (b) detrended data. All data are five-year triangular filtered

sec.p: Consequently, as R650;700 (reflecting chlorophyll a and its derivates) correlated best to temperature, it was used to develop an annual temperature calibration model for Duckhole Lake: R = 0.56, pauto < 0.05, RMSEP = 0.21°C, where both R and p were adjusted for autocorrelation.

sec.title: Reconstructed annual (January–December) mean temperature
sec.p: This model was used to reconstruct annual mean temperature over the last c. 950 years. The period from 49 to 61.6 cm (i.e. c. ad 1450–1600) was problematic because of large increases in the organic-based proxies (Figure 2), which indicated a ‘no-analogue’ situation in comparison to the calibration period. Consequently, this period was not used in the temperature reconstruction. This means the final temperature reconstruction spanned from c. ad 1050 to 1450 and 1600 to present.

The annual mean temperature reconstruction indicates varying warmer and cooler conditions in southern Tasmania over the last c. 950 years (Figure 5). The most notable features include: (i) a cool period at the start of the record c. ad 1050, which was followed by a steady warming trend until the late c. ad 1100s; (ii) a brief, relatively intense cool period in the c. mid ad 1200s, followed by generally warmer conditions in the c. ad 1300s; (iii) a generally warm period from the mid c. 1700s to late 1800s; and (iv) a marked cool period at the start of the 20th century before warmer temperatures since c. ad 1960.

caption.p: Duckhole Lake annual mean temperature reconstruction: (a) non-detrended; and (b) detrended.

Note: black line = original five-year filtered temperature reconstruction, red line = 21-year filtered data, grey shading = RMSEP determined errors, blue line = instrumental data. Horizontal line in (a) is the calibration period mean annual temperature. Horizontal dashed lines in (a) indicate the temperature range of the meteorological data (five-year filtered data). Values outside this range should be interpreted with caution.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: This study provides the first attempt to develop a high resolution quantitative temperature record from lake sediments in Tasmania. A calibration model was developed between the area of the trough from 650 to 700 nm, which represents chlorophyll a and its derivates, and annual mean temperature. This model was applied to the remainder of the sediment core to develop a c. 950 year quantitative annual mean temperature reconstruction. The first part of the discussion evaluates the calibration model and its application. The second part provides a paleoclimate interpretation with comparisons to other Southern Hemisphere studies.

sec.title: Calibration model – evaluation
sec.p: In regions where annually laminated lake sediments are not available it is necessary to rely on a combination of other dating methods to develop a sediment chronology. Based on the 210Pb age-model, the calibration period (ad 1911–2000) was contained in the top 15 cm of sediment and the maximum period covered by each 2 mm layer was 1.9 years (average 0.5 years). This is within the range recommended for CIT (i.e. at least 50 data points for a 100-year long calibration period; von Gunten et al., 2012).

Due to the low concentrations of 210Pb, 226Ra and 137Cs in the Southern Hemisphere (Appleby, 2008), 210Pb and 137Cs dating may be problematic and the errors are usually higher than in studies from the Northern Hemisphere. In this study, 210Pb and 137Cs dating were possible, despite relatively low activities as alpha spectroscopy for 210Pb was used. The errors for both 210Pb and 137Cs in this study were comparable with other studies in the Australasian region (Harrison et al., 2003). 137Cs is often below detection in Australasia as fallout levels from atomic bomb testing were approximately three times lower than for the Northern Hemisphere (Leslie and Hancock, 2008). Fortunately in this study, 137Cs was above detection level and a peak in 137Cs activity (ad 1964) occurred at 4.5 cm (ad 1964), which allowed the 210Pb age model to be constrained to this point. This was confirmed by comparing the constrained 210Pb chronology to the start of 137Cs activity in the sediment (7.5 cm). The ‘first appearance’ of 137Cs in sediments corresponds to ad 1954–1955 (Hancock et al., 2011) and the derived age for 7.5 cm based on the constrained 210Pb age model was ad 1952 ± 2.4 years (Figure 2), which suggests constraining the 210Pb to the 137Cs peak at 4.5 cm is appropriate.

R650;700 and RABD660;670 are calculated based on reflectance between 650–700 nm and 590–730 nm, respectively. Both chlorophyll a (derived from higher plants and algae) and b (derived from higher plants, chlorophytes and euglenophytes) reflect in this range and their spectra generally overlap (Leeben al., 2010). The TOC:TN ratio indicated organic matter was primarily terrestrially derived (as it was > 20 throughout the sediment core; Figure 3; Meyers, 1994). In terms of the CIT model in this study, we suggest that higher temperature leads to increased plant production and therefore more chlorophyll-related products in the lake sediment. The VIS-RS chlorophyll-related proxies R650;700 and RABD660;670 were highly significantly correlated to TOC (see sediment geochemistry section), which also suggests they are indicative of plant production.

The high correlation between R650;700, RABD660;670 and temperature, an absence of a correlation with precipitation and an average of > 900 mm/yr precipitation during the calibration period means precipitation is unlikely to be a limiting factor and suggests the chlorophyll-related products in the lake sediment are primarily driven by temperature. It is possible that further back in time precipitation may have influenced plant growth and disentangling the response of chlorophyll-based proxies to temperature and precipitation may need further consideration. However, as outlined in the Introduction, a fundamental assumption of any calibration-based approach is that the relationship between the proxy and the variable reconstructed does not change over time. In this study we apply this assumption but accept that further studies from southern Tasmania will be required to test the reproducibility of the results presented here.

Leeben et al. (2010) also found that absorption centered around 670 nm mainly represented land-derived organic matter in their lake sediments. While there may be a lag between a change in temperature, the subsequent response of the vegetation, and material then being deposited in the lake, it is unlikely to be a long delay as the vegetation grows at the edge of the lake and many trees hang over it (Figure 1). Additionally, the temperature reconstruction was filtered by 21 years, which aims to take into account both the dating uncertainty and any potential lag or delay between a change in temperature, the vegetation response, and input of organic material to the sediment.

The period from c. ad 1450 to 1600 was excluded from the temperature reconstruction as it was a ‘no-analogue’ situation compared to the calibration period. This was also visually apparent when the sediment core was collected and sectioned, as 49–61.6 cm was a dark brown, highly organic band and different from the rest of the sediment core (Figure 2). All measured proxies also changed during this time (Figure 2). The cause of this large change is not known, but is unlikely to be just due to temperature. One possible explanation may be the occurrence of a bushfire in the catchment (Schindler, 2009).

sec.title: Comparisons with other Southern Hemisphere paleoclimate records
Tasmania
sec.p: Cook et al. (1991, 2000) developed a warm season (November–April) temperature reconstruction based on Lagarostrobos franklinii (Huon Pine) tree rings from Mt Read, western Tasmania (Figure 6a). Their main findings demonstrated that temperatures since ad 1965 have been among the warmest in the last 3592 years (Cook et al., 2000). They also found significant correlations between southern Indian Ocean sea surface temperatures and their warm season temperature reconstruction, and suggested that changes in atmospheric circulation may also be contributing to the Tasmanian temperature reconstruction (Cook et al., 2000).

caption.p: Comparison of the Duckhole Lake annual mean temperature reconstruction with other Southern Hemisphere mid-latitude records: (a) western Tasmania (Cook et al., 1991, 2000); (b) southern Tasmania (this study); (c) New Zealand South Island (redrawn from Cook et al., 2006) and New Zealand North Island (Xiong and Palmer 2000); (d) southern South America (Neukom et al., 2011) and northern and southern Patagonia (Villalba et al., 2003).

Note: (a) and (c) are warm season (November–April) and summer (January–March and February–March) temperature reconstructions, respectively; (b) and (d) are based on annual temperature reconstructions. The horizontal grey lines for (a), (b) and (c) indicate the instrumental mean temperature values for each location.

sec.p: There are some similarities between the temperature reconstructions from western and southern Tasmania (this study), in particular from c. ad 1050 to 1200s when both showed an overall warming trend until the end of the c. ad 1100s, and during the ad 1200s when two cooler periods occurred at similar times. Both records also indicate cool conditions at the start of the 20th century, followed by warming (Figure 6a and b). However, they also show distinct differences (e.g. from c. ad 1380 to 1450 and 1600 to 1820). This is not unexpected as both records represent different aspects of temperature (i.e. warm season vs. annual), and although the sites are less than 200 km apart, they are from quite different regions of climate and topography: Mt Read, western Tasmania, is subalpine and relatively high elevation (950 m a.s.l.; Cook et al., 1991); Duckhole Lake, southern Tasmania, is a lowland site (150 m a.s.l.). Consequently, the two records are not necessarily directly comparable, but instead provide insights into both warm season (Cook et al., 1991, 2000) and annual (this study) temperature variability in two different climate zones in Tasmania. Further work is needed to determine how reproducible the variability of each temperature record is and how they compare to larger-scale regional seasonal and annual changes.

sec.title: New Zealand
sec.p: Based on a tree ring chronology from Oroko Swamp (43ºS, 110 m a.s.l.), Cook et al., (2002) identified initially cool conditions from ad 993 to 1091, followed by steadily increasing temperatures until the mid ad 1100s. This transition from cool conditions and steadily increasing temperatures also appears to have occurred in southern Tasmania (Figure 6b and c). Two periods of warmer conditions in New Zealand were inferred from ad 1137 to 1177 and 1210 to 1260, before cool conditions from ad 1260 to 1340 and fluctuating temperatures until ad 1470 (Cook et al., 2002). The first warm period identified by Cook et al. (2002) coincides with warming conditions in southern Tasmania, but the two records differ after the end of ad 1100s until the 20th century (Figure 6b and c).

New Zealand glacial and tree ring evidence suggests there were multiple cool periods from ad 1610 to 1750 (Burrows, 1982; Cook et al., 2002; Schaefer et al., 2009; Xiong and Palmer, 2000; Figure 6c). Temperatures in southern Tasmania also appear to have steadily decreased during this period (Figure 6b). Xiong and Palmer (2000) developed a network of 23 sites to reconstruct past late summer (February–March) temperatures for 39–41ºS in New Zealand (all sites ≥ 860 m a.s.l.; Figure 6c). The reconstruction differs from the western and southern Tasmanian temperature reconstructions except in the 20th century, where all show the same initially cool conditions, followed by warming in the second half of the 20th century (Figure 6).

sec.title: South America
sec.p: Cooler conditions occurred in central Chile from c. ad 970 to 1040 and ad 1080 to 1140, followed by warmer conditions until c. ad 1350 (von Gunten et al., 2009). Cooler conditions occurred in southern Tasmania during this time but, unlike central Chile, the trend towards warmer conditions was interrupted in the c. ad 1200s by two relatively brief cool periods. Further south, glacier advances in southern South America (41–55°S) started in the mid ad 1200s (Koch and Kilian, 2005), which coincides with generally cooler conditions in southern Tasmania. The three coldest summer decades identified by Neukom et al. (2011) in southern South America occurred from ad 1398 to 1494. A drop in temperature occurred in southern Tasmania from the late ad 1300s to mid-1400s (Figure 6b). From ad 1550 to 1720 glacier advances occurred in the Andes at 35°S (Espizua and Pitte, 2009) and temperatures were cooler in southern South America (Villalba et al., 2003). The latter part of this period coincides with generally cooler conditions in southern Tasmania (Figure 6b), except at the start of the ad 1600s when temperatures were relatively warm.

Temperatures in southern Tasmania had an overall decreasing trend throughout most of the ad 1800s, although did remain above the 20th century average. A transition to cooler conditions has also been identified in southern South American sites (Bertrand et al., 2005; Espizua and Pitte, 2009; Neukom et al., 2011; Villalba et al., 2003; Figure 6d), western Tasmania (Cook et al., 2000; Figure 6a) and New Zealand (Xiong and Palmer, 2000; Figure 6c) during this period. However, the timing and amplitude of the decrease in temperature differs between records. This may be due to a number of factors including spatial differences in temperature change and/or seasonal/annual differences between the records and/or dating uncertainties associated with the individual records.

sec.title: How does the 20th century compare to the last c. 950 years?
sec.p: The most obvious feature of the Duckhole Lake temperature record for the 20th century is the cool period in the early ad 1900s followed by warming since the ad 1960s (Figure 5). This cool period was also identified in the instrumental data for the calibration period (Figure 5a), the warm season temperature reconstruction from western Tasmania (Figure 6a) and sea surface temperature records off the west coast of Tasmania (Cook et al., 2000). It also overlaps with part of the coldest period found in New Zealand instrumental records (ad 1900–1935; Cook et al., 1991) and is reflected in New Zealand tree ring records (Cook et al., 2002; Xiong and Palmer, 2000; Figure 6c). A cool period was also found in southern South America (Neukom et al., 2011; Villalba et al., 2003; Figure 6d).

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: This study provides the first application of VIS-RS to develop a high resolution quantitative temperature record from lake sediments in Tasmania, and more generally in the Australasian region. The model was based on a significant, positive correlation between reflectance data that is indicative of chlorophyll content in the sediments and annual mean temperature. No significant correlations with precipitation were found. Measurements of TOC and TN indicated that the organic material in the sediment was primarily terrestrially derived and we suggest that warmer (cooler) temperatures result in more (less) plant growth and therefore more (less) chlorophyll-related products in the lake sediments. This model was applied to the remainder of the sediment core and temperature was reconstructed over the last c. 950 years. The temperature reconstructed indicated some pronounced temperature changes, in particular a cool period c. ad 1050, after which temperatures steadily increased and peaked in the mid–late ad 1100s. This trend has previously been found in temperature reconstructions based on tree ring studies in western Tasmania and New Zealand. Temperatures steadily decreased in southern Tasmania during the ad 1600s. While evidence of decreasing temperatures occurred prior to this in western Tasmania and New Zealand, cool conditions have been found in several southern South American records during this time. Temperatures appeared to be relatively stable in southern Tasmania after this until the start of the 20th century, when they rapidly decreased, before increasing since the mid-20th century. This was also seen in records from western Tasmania, New Zealand and southern Patagonia, although the timing of the lowest temperature values varied between the records. Since c. ad 1950s temperatures increased in all regions.

While this study provides new data, further studies from Tasmania and the rest of the Australasian region are needed, in particular to highlight common features amongst the records and, where differences exist, to determine whether these are due to seasonal versus annual variability, spatial differences, or differences between the responses of different archives.

ack.p: We would like to thank Tim Trevaskis and Anthony O’Hern for field assistance; Robb Clifton for field equipment; Michael Grose for supplying the CSIRO AWAP meteorological data; Christian Kamenik for his statistical expertise; Luca Siffert, Stefan Hunziker and Daniela Fischer for analytical assistance; Rixt de Jong, Louise Newman, Joelle Gergis, Julie Elbert and John Gibson for discussions; Andrew Wakefield for geological and botanical advice; Lucien von Gunten and Jennifer Harrison for 210Pb advice; and Katarzyna Dziegielewska for proof reading the manuscript. We would also like to thank the reviewers for their careful and considerate comments, which have helped to improve the manuscript. This work contributes to the PAGES Aus2k network.
